items.title: When I press OK my input dialogue box keeps re-appearing
items.body:
I am making an Outliner App where you can Add nodes and edit them as a kind of to-do list however when I add a node and press "OK" the input box will re-appear and I cannot find the issue so some help would be greatly appreciated.

I tried to use a boolean way already and managed to fix the "cancel" button however the OK button and X button in the top right still make the box re-appear

Controller class:

public class OutlinerController implements ActionListener {

    private OutlinerModel model;
    private OutlinerView view;

    public OutlinerController(OutlinerModel model, OutlinerView view) {
        this.model = model;
        this.view = view;

        // Register this controller as the listener for the buttons in the view
        view.addButtonListener(this);
        view.addEditButtonListener(this);
        view.addDeleteButtonListener(this);
        view.addCompleteButtonListener(this);
        view.addSearchButtonListener(this);
    }

public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
    DefaultMutableTreeNode selectedNode = (DefaultMutableTreeNode) view.getTree().getLastSelectedPathComponent();
    if (e.getSource() == view.getAddButton()) {
        boolean adding = true;
        while (adding) {
            // Add a new node to the selected node 
            String nodeName = JOptionPane.showInputDialog("Enter node name:");
            if (nodeName == null) { // Cancel button pressed
                adding = false;
            } else if (nodeName.trim().equals("")) { // Empty name entered
                JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(view.getTree(), "Node name cannot be empty.", "Error", JOptionPane.ERROR_MESSAGE);
            } else {
                DefaultMutableTreeNode newNode = new DefaultMutableTreeNode(nodeName);
                model.getTreeModel().insertNodeInto(newNode, selectedNode, selectedNode.getChildCount());
                // Expand the selected node to show the newly added node 
                view.getTree().expandPath(new TreePath(selectedNode.getPath()));
            }
        }
    } if (e.getSource() == view.getEditButton()) {
        // Edit the selected node's name 
        String nodeName = JOptionPane.showInputDialog("Enter new node name:");
        selectedNode.setUserObject(nodeName);
        model.getTreeModel().nodeChanged(selectedNode);
    }  if (e.getSource() == view.getDeleteButton()) {
        // Remove the selected node from the JTree 
        model.getTreeModel().removeNodeFromParent(selectedNode);
    }  if (e.getSource() == view.getCompleteButton()) {
        // Mark the selected node as complete 
        selectedNode.setUserObject(selectedNode.getUserObject() + " [Complete]");
        model.getTreeModel().nodeChanged(selectedNode);
    }  if (e.getSource() == view.getSearchButton()) {
        // Get the search term from the user 
        String searchTerm = JOptionPane.showInputDialog("Enter search term:");
        DefaultMutableTreeNode searchResult = searchNode(model.getRoot(), searchTerm);
        // If a node is found with the given search term, select and scroll to that node in the JTree 
        if (searchResult != null) {
            TreePath path = new TreePath(searchResult.getPath());
            view.getTree().setSelectionPath(path);
            view.getTree().scrollPathToVisible(path);
        } else {
            // If no node is found with the given search term, show a message to the user 
           view.displayErrorMessage("No node found with the given search term");
        }
    }
}

    private DefaultMutableTreeNode searchNode(DefaultMutableTreeNode node, String searchTerm) {
        // Check if the current node matches the search term 
        if (node.getUserObject().toString().toLowerCase().contains(searchTerm.toLowerCase())) {
            return node;
        }
        // Recursively search the child nodes of the current node 
        for (int i = 0; i < node.getChildCount(); i++) {
            DefaultMutableTreeNode childNode = (DefaultMutableTreeNode) node.getChildAt(i);
            DefaultMutableTreeNode result = searchNode(childNode, searchTerm);
            if (result != null) {
                return result;
            }
        }

        // If no node is found with the given search term, return null 
        return null;

    }
        private void searchNode(String searchString) {
        // Get the root of the JTree 
        DefaultMutableTreeNode rootNode = (DefaultMutableTreeNode) view.getTree().getModel().getRoot();

        // Traverse the JTree and find nodes that match the search string 
        searchNodeHelper(searchString, rootNode);
    }

    private void searchNodeHelper(String searchString, DefaultMutableTreeNode node) {

        // Get the user object of the node and convert it to lowercase 
        String nodeString = node.getUserObject().toString().toLowerCase();

        // Check if the node string contains the search string 
        if (nodeString.contains(searchString)) {

            // If the node string contains the search string, expand its path and highlight it 
            TreePath path = new TreePath(node.getPath());
            view.getTree().expandPath(path);
            view.getTree().setSelectionPath(path);
            return;

        }

        // If the node string does not contain the search string, recursively check its children 
        for (int i = 0; i < node.getChildCount(); i++) {
            DefaultMutableTreeNode childNode = (DefaultMutableTreeNode) node.getChildAt(i);
            searchNodeHelper(searchString, childNode);
        }

    }

}

comments.body_markdown: applicationContext.getBean() is pure Spring. Only @Component (or its extensions) will cause a class to be placed in application context, not @Named. You need to access CdiBiz business with @Inject. Also javax.inject has moved to jakarta.inject so you should be using a jakarta.inject dependency with 17+

You need to access CdiBiz business with @Inject. Also javax.inject has moved to jakarta.inject so you should be using a jakarta.inject dependency with 17+

items.title: org.springframework.beans.factory.NoSuchBeanDefinitionException while using CDI @Named and @Inject
items.body:
I can access the beans just fine when I replace the annotations with their Spring equivalent (@Component and @Autowired), but it won't work with CDI. javax.inject is present as a dependency in the pom.xml file and I see javax.inject-1.jar in my Maven dependencies with 6 annotation definitions, including Named and Inject. Here's my App file -

package tempTestCdiError;

import org.slf4j.Logger;
import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;
import org.springframework.boot.SpringApplication;
import org.springframework.boot.autoconfigure.SpringBootApplication;
import org.springframework.context.ConfigurableApplicationContext;

@SpringBootApplication
public class CdiTestApp {
    static Logger LOGGER = LoggerFactory.getLogger(CdiTestApp.class);

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        ConfigurableApplicationContext applicationContext = SpringApplication.run(CdiTestApp.class, args);
        CdiBiz business = applicationContext.getBean(CdiBiz.class);
        LOGGER.info("{}, dao-{}", business, business.getCdiDao());
    }
}

The error shows up because of this line - CdiBiz business = applicationContext.getBean(CdiBiz.class);

Edit: Switching from javax.inject to jakarta.inject solves the issue
